note: In Poland, cryptocurrencies are considered virtual currencies and are subject to taxation under the Personal Income Tax (PIT) and Corporate Income Tax (CIT) laws.
Profits from cryptocurrency transactions are taxed at a flat rate of 19% as income from capital gains for individuals and as corporate income for businesses.
Taxable events include exchanging virtual currency for legal tender, exchanging virtual currency for goods, services, or property rights, and settling liabilities with virtual currency.
Exchanging one cryptocurrency for another is not considered a taxable event in Poland.
Losses from cryptocurrency investments can be deducted and carried forward to offset future gains, provided they are properly documented.
Income from cryptocurrency mining is considered revenue from business activity and is subject to taxation under standard PIT or CIT rates.
Polish taxpayers are required to report their cryptocurrency gains and losses in their annual tax returns, maintaining detailed records of all transactions.
The Polish government has implemented Anti-Money Laundering (AML) regulations that apply to entities providing services related to virtual currencies, such as exchanges and wallet providers.

As of December 2024, a draft law proposes significant changes to the crypto-assets market, including the introduction of a Crypto-Asset Service Provider (CASP) license and the abolition of the existing Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP) register.
The proposed law also includes a ban on lending in crypto-assets or brokering loan transactions involving crypto-assets.
The draft law shortens the transition period for compliance, requiring entities to obtain a CASP license by September 30, 2025, to continue operations.
It's essential for investors and businesses to stay informed about the evolving tax regulations and proposed legislative changes in Poland to ensure accurate reporting and compliance with the law.
